results.abstract: John Tierney Op-Ed column on Richard Branson's plan to take off from new spaceport in New Mexico desert; reports his company, Virgin Galactic, has already collected more than $10 million from would-be passengers like architect Philippe Starck, actress Victoria Principal and director Bryan Singer, with waiting list that includes William Shatner and Stephen Hawking; suggests there may be no need for NASA to poke around in Earth orbit and suggests offering prizes for making actual progress on Mars mission
results.snippet: Offering prizes for innovations in space would buy a lot more R.&.D. than you would ever get by giving the funds to NASA.
results.lead_paragraph: NASA still doesn't have the money to go back to the Moon, much less head to Mars, but there is good news for space explorers. Someone else is on the job. Richard Branson, who's selling rides into space for $200,000 (cash up front), is close to sealing a deal to take off from a new spaceport in the New Mexico desert. The first flights are scheduled in three years, and his company, Virgin Galactic, has already collected more than $10 million from future passengers.

results.abstract: Flynn Larsen letter likes idea of spurring research and development in space travel by offering prize money for private-sector solutions, but says research is desperately needed in other areas (Dec 6 John Tierney Op-Ed column); drawing

headline.main: Our Vision in Space (and Here on Earth)

results.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Go West, Young Astronaut'' (column, Dec. 6):     I like John Tierney's idea to spur research and development in space travel by offering prize money for private-sector solutions, but how about awarding prizes for the much...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Go West, Young Astronaut'' (column, Dec. 6): I like John Tierney's idea to spur research and development in space travel by offering prize money for private-sector solutions, but how about awarding prizes for the much more desperately needed research and development on developing solar power and other non-fossil fuel sources as a viable source of energy on a mass scale?

results.snippet: 9 P.M. (NBC) THREE WISHES -- ''I Wish to Be Bill Gates.'' In the season finale, three very young people enjoy a taste of their wildest career dreams. An aspiring actress is given a role on NBC's daytime soap ''Passions.'' A future astronaut is sent...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) THREE WISHES -- ''I Wish to Be Bill Gates.'' In the season finale, three very young people enjoy a taste of their wildest career dreams. An aspiring actress is given a role on NBC's daytime soap ''Passions.'' A future astronaut is sent to space camp. Kiyaan Vazirzadeh, a 10-year-old who wants to run Microsoft when he grows up, gets to try out the job for a day and meet the company's founder -- his idol, Bill Gates (above right, with Kiyaan and Amy Grant, the show's host) -- in the process. 7 P.M. (Hallmark) CELEBRATE! CHRISTMAS WITH MAYA ANGELOU -- Ms. Angelou, the novelist and poet, invites viewers into her North Carolina home. She also invites about 200 friends and relatives. 8 P.M. (Hallmark) C. S. LEWIS: BEYOND NARNIA -- The fantasy movie ''The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe'' opens today. Those who don't rush out to the theater may be interested in the life of Lewis (Anton Rodgers), the deeply religious British scholar who wrote the Narnia books. Until now, Lewis was best known to moviegoers as the man Anthony Hopkins played, opposite Debra Winger, in ''Shadowlands.'' 9 P.M. (A&E) BIOGRAPHY: ANGELINA JOLIE -- Ms. Jolie (right) is an Oscar winner (''Girl, Interrupted''), a goodwill ambassador (for the United Nations) and, at 30, the villain in the most scandalous Hollywood home-wrecking triangle since Elizabeth Taylor, Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher in the 1950's. And Brad Pitt is adopting her children. 9 P.M. (ABC) HOPE & FAITH -- Faith (Kelly Ripa) spends far too much on Christmas gifts this year. But she gives her brother-in-law (Ted McGinley) a fake gold watch. 9:30 P.M. (Fox) MALCOLM IN THE MIDDLE -- Hal and Lois (Bryan Cranston and Jane Kaczmarek) have nothing to spend on Christmas gifts this year. So they decree that all presents have to be homemade. 2 A.M. (TCM) NEVER ON SUNDAY (1960). Melina Mercouri stars as the original happy hooker, a self-possessed prostitute making her own rules in a Greek port city. But an American (the Connecticut-born Jules Dassin, left, who also wrote and directed, with Mercouri) tries to reform her. Mercouri was named best actress (tying with Jeanne Moreau) at the Cannes Film Festival. Manos Hadjidakis's title song took home an Oscar. ANITA GATES

headline.main: A Museum Shop Is the Cure for Re-Gifting

results.snippet: ONE alternative to seeing the same items wherever you go for holiday shopping is the abundance of unusual and reasonably priced items to be found at museum gift shops throughout Westchester.     Most gift shops reflect the museums' themes and current...
results.lead_paragraph: ONE alternative to seeing the same items wherever you go for holiday shopping is the abundance of unusual and reasonably priced items to be found at museum gift shops throughout Westchester. Most gift shops reflect the museums' themes and current exhibitions; all offer a little serenity amid the harried pace that goes along with this time of year.
